title: Purple Aces men learn from heartbreaking OT thriller
description: EVANSVILLE, Ind. (WEHT) ‚Äî After suffering another heartbreaking loss, University of Evansville men‚Äôs basketball head coach David Ragland said the team is going to take the loss as another lesson learned. The Purple Aces got out to a 13 point lead in the first half Tuesday night against Bradley before the Braves came back and [‚Ä¶]
fullText:
EVANSVILLE, Ind. (WEHT) ‚Äî After suffering another heartbreaking loss, University of Evansville men‚Äôs basketball head coach David Ragland said the team is going to take the loss as another lesson learned.

The Purple Aces got out to a 13 point lead in the first half Tuesday night against Bradley before the Braves came back and forced overtime.

UE failed to come up with a crucial rebound in the closing seconds of OT, that would have given them a chance to win or tie the game.

Head Coach Ragland said though the loss stings there are some positives to take away from the game.

‚ÄúIt is frustrating, you know we do want to win. You know it‚Äôs frustrating losing as many games as we have period, but especially as close games like we have. No, but at the same time like if you‚Äôre not playing in close games then you don‚Äôt know what to improve upon to get, make those close games victories. And the other part man is just being grateful for to be in opportunities where you do can turn your fortunes you know with a couple adjustments.‚Äù

Evansville will have a chance to bounce back Tuesday, January 20th, at UIC at 7 p.m. The game is set to be streamed on ESPN Plus.

title: UE women trending in the right direction
description: EVANSVILLE, Ind. (WEHT) ‚Äî Despite struggling for most of the season, the University of Evansville women‚Äôs basketball team is starting to show growth on the hardwood. The Purple Aces dropped their last game on the road at Illinois State last Sunday, but won their first two consecutive games on the year earlier in the week. [‚Ä¶]
fullText:
EVANSVILLE, Ind. (WEHT) ‚Äî Despite struggling for most of the season, the University of Evansville women‚Äôs basketball team is starting to show growth on the hardwood.

The Purple Aces dropped their last game on the road at Illinois State last Sunday, but won their first two consecutive games on the year earlier in the week. Looking over their schedule, you‚Äôll see they haven‚Äôt lost a game by more than 10 points in over a month.

UE is finally starting to click as a team as they find other contributors in the lineup outside of just Camryn Runner and Logan Luebbers Palmer.

The team isn‚Äôt where they want to be just yet, but they‚Äôre trending in the right direction.

‚ÄúI think we just needed to gain some experience. We played so many games on the road, didn‚Äôt have a lot of opportunities to gain that winning momentum at home that you get with a young team. So we were slugging it through on the road against some really good teams and gained some toughness along the way and I think finally got to a point where really them as players and as a group they just went we‚Äôve got to be tougher for 40 minutes. We‚Äôre tough for 30, we‚Äôve got to be tough for 40. So I think we‚Äôre just seeing this young team grow up each game and getting better and better.‚Äù

Evansville will be back in action Friday, January 16th, against UIC. The game is scheduled to be streamed on ESPN Plus.

title: New Model Fails to Explain Near-Death Experiences, Scientists Say
description: An ambitious effort to create a neurophysiological paradigm to explain near-death experiences has failed to capture many fascinating and often perplexing aspects of people‚Äôs brushes with death, top University of Virginia experts argue in a new paper. UVA near-death researchers Bruce Greyson, MD, and Marieta Pehlivanova, PhD, laud the international team of scientists who developed [‚Ä¶]
fullText:
An ambitious effort to create a neurophysiological paradigm to explain near-death experiences has failed to capture many fascinating and often perplexing aspects of people‚Äôs brushes with death, top University of Virginia experts argue in a new paper.

UVA near-death researchers Bruce Greyson, MD, and Marieta Pehlivanova, PhD, laud the international team of scientists who developed the model, called Neurophysiological Evolutionary Psychological Theory Understanding Near-Death Experience, or NEPTUNE. The NEPTUNE team aimed to bring scientific rigor to understanding near-death experiences (NDEs) ‚Äì a goal shared by Greyson and Pehlivanova. But the UVA experts say the model, for all its sophistication, leaves far too many unanswered questions to be considered a satisfactory solution to the mysteries of NDEs.

‚ÄúThe NEPTUNE model was a pioneering attempt to explain NDEs, but it selectively ignored scientific evidence that contradicts the model and failed to address some of the most important and defining parts of NDEs,‚Äù said Greyson, part of the Division of Perceptual Studies at UVA‚Äôs School of Medicine.

In their new paper, Greyson and Pehlivanova outline many facets of NDEs that the NEPTUNE model ‚Äì and neurophysiology more broadly ‚Äì still cannot explain. For example, the NEPTUNE researchers argue that near-death ‚Äúhallucinations‚Äù could be caused by changes in blood brain gases, endorphins or other chemical or electrical activity in the brain.

But Pehlivanova and Greyson note that neurological hallucinations typically only involve a single sense, such as hearing or sight. Those types of single-sense hallucinations do not align, the UVA researchers say, with the robust and often life-changing encounters near-death experiencers report having with loved ones or even with people they have never met. Experiencers can often recall what they saw, heard, smelled and touched while dead, and the encounters are often burned into their brains for decades ‚Äì unlike hallucinations, which are quickly forgotten.

The NEPTUNE group also advanced a potential explanation for the out-of-body experiences near-death experiencers sometimes report. In these instances, experiencers feel disconnected from their physical forms and sometimes recall looking down on their own bodies. The NEPTUNE scientists pointed to two studies suggesting that this may be the result of the activation of a particular region in the brain, the temporoparietal junction (TPJ). But Greyson and Pehlivanova counter that the experiences reported in those two studies are ‚Äúquite unlike‚Äù the out-of-body experiences described in NDEs. During TPJ activation, there is a sense of disembodiment, but visual perception remains normal ‚Äì experiencers don‚Äôt see their own forms or feel like they can move about independent of their bodies as near-death experiencers do.

Further, the UVA researchers note that electrical stimulation studies have already tested the TPJ theory. Stimulating the brain region produced visual hallucinations, but study participants did not believe they had left their bodies, Greyson and Pehlivanova write: ‚ÄúThere is no evidence that electrical brain stimulation has ever produced accurate perception of anything not visible to the physical eyes, or that persists when eyes are closed, or that is from an out-of-body perspective ‚Äì all features observed in spontaneous OBEs.‚Äù

While Pehlivanova and Greyson raise several additional concerns about the NEPTUNE model, they were eager to applaud its developers for their efforts. ‚ÄúMartial et al have done a monumental job summarizing the major arguments in this field, relying on both theoretical and empirical contributions from the NDE literature and broader major research,‚Äù they write. But they say a lack of empirical data and other flaws in the NEPTUNE model raise concerns that ‚Äútemper our enthusiasm for the model and our confidence that it can provide a comprehensive explanation for NDEs.‚Äù

In other words, neurophysiology still can‚Äôt explain near-death experiences, Pehlivanova and Greyson say. But they are eager for the conversation to continue.

‚ÄúNDEs are typically triggered by physiological events, so it makes sense to explore those connections and look for cause-and-effect. But this effort is just at the beginning stage, and it is important to keep being open-minded as we continue the search,‚Äù Greyson said. ‚ÄúUnderstanding NDEs can unlock the door to larger questions about consciousness and the brain. We hope the quest to appreciate all aspects of NDEs will lead us not just to mapping the triggers of NDEs but also to their meaning and to a better understanding of the boundary between life and death.‚Äù

Greyson and Pehlivanova have published their response in the scientific journal Psychology of Consciousness: Theory, Research and Practice. The article is open access, meaning it is free to read.

Established in 1967 under the leadership of UVA psychiatrist Ian Stevenson, MD, DOPS stands as the most productive university-based research group in the world dedicated to exploring phenomena that challenge conventional scientific paradigms concerning human consciousness. At the core of DOPS‚Äô research mission lies the commitment to rigorous evaluation of empirical evidence surrounding exceptional human experiences and capacities, including utilization of a state-of-the-art neuroimaging lab. DOPS extends its focus beyond fundamental empirical research and explores the profound implications of such research for scientific theory and society at large. By actively sharing insights and findings, DOPS strives to contribute meaningfully to the understanding of consciousness, bridging the gap between scientific inquiry and public awareness.

Article written by¬†Josh Barney, Deputy Public Information Officer, UVA Health.

fullText:
EVANSVILLE, Ind (WEHT) ‚Äì After starting the season (3-13) overall and (0-6) in Ohio Valley Conference, University of Southern Indiana men‚Äôs basketball team head coach Stan Gouard said changes are coming for his team.

Gouard said we can expect changes to the lineup and gameplan as the Screaming Eagles move forward through the season and look for a solution to get out of their slump. The decision to make changes to the rotation may help the team find something that works better or even light a fire under some players to improve their play.

‚ÄúI‚Äôm not into worry about guys feelings right now. As coaches our feelings are hurt as well. You know I think we have enough team guys on our team to understand that what we‚Äôre doing right now, the lineups we have are not working. You know hopefully someone responds to you know sitting on the bench, but not playing as much. That‚Äôs what competitors do and we just hope that they respond to it and prove us wrong because they‚Äôre going to play harder or be more disciplined in terms of what we‚Äôre trying to get done as a team.‚Äù

USI will face Tennessee Tech on the road Thursday, January 15th, at 7:30 p.m. The game is set to stream on ESPN Plus.

title: El Paso Locomotive FC introduce Junior Gonzalez and Mike DiGiulio
description: EL PASO, Texas (KTSM) ‚Äî A new era of El Paso Locomotive FC officially began Tuesday as the club introduced its new president and general manager along with a new head coach at Southwest University Park. The Locomotive officially welcomed Mike DiGiulio as the new president and general manager and Junior Gonzalez as the new [‚Ä¶]
fullText:
EL PASO, Texas (KTSM) ‚Äî A new era of El Paso Locomotive FC officially began Tuesday as the club introduced its new president and general manager along with a new head coach at Southwest University Park.

A new chapter starts here üì∏

El Paso Locomotive FC introduced President & General Manager Mike Digiulio and Head Coach Junior Gonzalez at today‚Äôs press conference. #VamosLocos #VamosElP pic.twitter.com/HewhFz2OIs

‚Äî El Paso Locomotive FC (@eplocomotivefc) January 13, 2026

The Locomotive officially welcomed Mike DiGiulio as the new president and general manager and Junior Gonzalez as the new head coach during an event at the WestStar Club.

DiGiulio takes over the role previously held by Andrew Forrest. He arrives in El Paso after spending the past five years as president of Monterey Bay FC, another club competing in the USL Championship.

Gonzalez brings 25 years of coaching experience, with stops across Major League Soccer, the USL Championship and MLS NEXT Pro. Most recently, he served as head coach of LAFC II.

Gonzalez becomes the fifth head coach in El Paso Locomotive FC history.

Both DiGiulio and Gonzalez expressed excitement about leading the next chapter of the club as the Locomotive continue building their roster ahead of the 2026 season.

‚ÄúI‚Äôm extremely excited,‚Äù Gonzalez said. ‚ÄúI‚Äôve been in quite a long journey, and I‚Äôve been in many different environments for this opportunity, and I don‚Äôt take it lightly to be part of the community of El Paso. And our goal is to have success and win trophies, but also to develop young and veteran players to become a team and be good in the community.‚Äù

‚ÄúI have a real love for the sport,‚Äù DiGiulio said. ‚ÄúI have a real love for the league. I think the USL is a tremendous opportunity in the future. I believe what we have coming in the next several years is going to be special. My goal and our goal is to be one of those clubs that are the elite thought of clubs in USL.‚Äù

El Paso will open the season on March 7, hosting Colorado Springs Switchbacks FC at Southwest University Park.

title: China limits Nvidia chip purchases to special circumstances, Information reports
description: The Chinese government this week told some tech companies it would only approve their purchases ‚Äãof Nvidia's H200 AI chips under special circumstances, such ‚Äåas for university research, the Information reported on Tuesday, citing two people with ‚Äådirect knowledge of the situation.  The move signals Beijing is remaining cautious about fully reopening the Chinese market to Nvidia, whose semiconductors are pivotal in operating the most advanced artificial intelligence applications and ‚Å†data centers.  China's government issued ‚Äåa "deliberately vague" directive, the report said, telling some technology firms to buy chips only when "necessary" but was ‚Äçunclear as to what that means.
fullText:
Jan 13 (Reuters) - The Chinese government this week told some tech companies it would only approve their purchases ‚Äãof Nvidia's H200 AI chips under special circumstances, such ‚Äåas for university research, the Information reported on Tuesday, citing two people with ‚Äådirect knowledge of the situation.

The move signals Beijing is remaining cautious about fully reopening the Chinese market to Nvidia, whose semiconductors are pivotal in operating the most advanced artificial intelligence applications and ‚Å†data centers.

China's government issued ‚Äåa "deliberately vague" directive, the report said, telling some technology firms to buy chips only when "necessary" but was ‚Äçunclear as to what that means.

The Information reported last week that China had asked some companies to halt their orders for the H200 ‚Äãchips, as it looked to prioritize domestic firms in their ‚Äårace to dominate AI.

Nvidia is caught between Washington and Beijing, as the U.S. weighs tighter export controls on its most advanced technology while China pushes to strengthen domestic AI capabilities and urges local firms to curb reliance on foreign tech.

"As principle, ensuring ‚Å†the smooth development of economic, trade, ‚Äãand technological cooperation is in the ‚Äãcommon interest of both China and the U.S.," Chinese Embassy spokesperson Liu Pengyu said when reached for ‚Äçcomment.

Nvidia did not ‚Å†respond to a Reuters request for comment.

The Chinese government plans to convene additional meetings with more companies to deliver ‚Å†the purchase directive, though it is unclear whether those sessions will include any ‚Äånew guidance, the report said.

title: Proposed Rust kernel extensions in place of eBPF
description: University researchers presented Rex at this month's Linux Plumbers Conference 2025 in Tokyo
fullText:
Rex: Proposed Safe Rust Kernel Extensions For The Linux Kernel, In Place Of eBPF

University researchers presented Rex at this month's Linux Plumbers Conference 2025 in Tokyo. Rex is designed for "safe and usable" Rust-based kernel extensions that could serve in place of eBPF programs for extending the Linux kernel functionality.
Still in development form and not yet any decision on upstreaming to the mainline Linux kernel, Rex is a Rust-based kernel extension framework with similar safety guarantees to eBPF. Rex relies on the safety of the Rust programming language paired with lightweight runtime protections.
Researchers from Virgina Tech and University of Illinois Urbana-Champaign presented at LPC 2025 on Rex. The Rex code hasn't been formally submitted yet to the mailing list for any formal review or attempt at upstreaming to the mainline kernel. Those wanting to check out the Rex documentation and code in its current form can find it via GitHub.
Embedded below is the full LPC 2025 session recording and there are also the associated PDF slides for the proposed Rust safe kernel extensions for Linux.
 75 Comments

title: Mammoth beat Senators 3-1 hours after NHL awards Utah 2027 Winter Classic
description: Lawson Crouse and John Marino scored in a 3:21 span in the first period, Karel Vejmelka made 33 saves and the Utah Mammoth beat the Ottawa Senators 3-1 on Wednesday night to cap a big day for the franchise.  The Mammoth won hours after the NHL announced the team will host the 2027 Winter Classic at the University of Utah's football stadium.  Clayton Keller assisted on the first-period goals, and Daniil But also scored.
fullText:
SALT LAKE CITY (AP) ‚Äî Lawson Crouse and John Marino scored in a 3:21 span in the first period, Karel Vejmelka made 33 saves and the Utah Mammoth beat the Ottawa Senators 3-1 on Wednesday night to cap a big day for the franchise.

The Mammoth won hours after the NHL announced the team will host the 2027 Winter Classic at the University of Utah's football stadium.

Clayton Keller assisted on the first-period goals, and Daniil But also scored. The Mammoth opened a seven-game homestand, rebounding from a 3-2 overtime loss to the New York Rangers on Monday night.

Ridly Greig scored for Ottawa, and Leevi Merilainen stopped 18 shots. Greig has scored in all four games he has played against Utah.

Crouse opened the scoring from the slot at 3:59, and Marino scored off a rebound at 7:20. Greig scored through a crowd in front for Ottawa with 2:19 left in the opening period.

But made it 3-1 at 5:41 of the third on a wild scramble in front. The goal survived a video review for goalie interference.

Ottawa has lost two in a row. The Senators had won two straight before a 5-3 home loss to Detroit on Monday night.

Senators: At Colorado on Thursday night.

Mammoth: Host St. Louis on Friday night.

AP NHL: https://apnews.com/hub/nhl

title: Ames native Tamin Lipsey a big part of first 15-0 start for No. 3 Iowa State
description: Iowa State point guard Tamin Lipsey, the senior who grew up near campus in Ames, is now part of something that had never been done by the Cyclones.  ‚ÄúWatching all those teams growing up and just realizing that I have a chance right now to make a footprint for Iowa State, and just the community of Ames and all of that, I never take for granted.‚Äù  Lipsey scored 24 points, overcoming some early foul trouble that kept him on the bench for nearly eight minutes in the first half.
fullText:
WACO, Texas (AP) ‚Äî Iowa State point guard Tamin Lipsey, the senior who grew up near campus in Ames, is now part of something that had never been done by the Cyclones. They have a 15-game winning streak to start the season.

‚ÄúI‚Äôve been a Cyclone all my life. Just got on the court four years ago, though,‚Äù Lipsey said Wednesday night following a 70-60 victory at Baylor. ‚ÄúWatching all those teams growing up and just realizing that I have a chance right now to make a footprint for Iowa State, and just the community of Ames and all of that, I never take for granted.‚Äù

Lipsey scored 24 points, overcoming some early foul trouble that kept him on the bench for nearly eight minutes in the first half. Joshua Jefferson had 19 points and 17 rebounds for Iowa State (15-0, 2-0 Big 12).

The Cyclones' 15-0 start and 15-game winning streak are both school records, surpassing a 14-0 start by the 2013-14 team that reached the Sweet 16 of the NCAA Tournament. They are one of six undefeated Division I teams, along with No. 1 Arizona, No. 2 Michigan, No. 10 Nebraska, No. 11 Vanderbilt and unranked Miami, Ohio.

‚ÄúI think these guys do such a great job at honoring all those who have come before us with the effort and the execution that they play with,‚Äù fifth-year Cyclones coach T.J. Otzelberger said. ‚ÄúSo it‚Äôs a great accomplishment. It‚Äôs a credit to the young men and how they work. And hopefully something that the past Cyclones who have been in this program and those that have invested can take tremendous pride in.‚Äù

Jefferson, a senior forward and second-year transfer from Saint Mary's, already had his sixth double-double of the season by halftime.

His long-3-pointer with 5 seconds left in the first half gave the Cyclones their first lead at 25-24. They never gave that up, starting the second half with a 14-1 run when six players scored and Jefferson capped it with a fast-break dunk.

‚ÄúA huge shot Joshua made just before the half," Otzelberger said. ‚ÄúA huge momentum play that carried into that second half.‚Äù

Lipsey has started all 115 of his games in four seasons with the Cyclones, including three NCAA Tournament appearances and a Sweet 16 in that time. He came out after his second foul with 17:12 left in the first half and didn't return until the 9:19 mark. He finally scored with 6:11 left in the first half, then had 20 points after halftime.

"I'd take him over any point guard in America," Otzelberger said. ‚ÄúObviously, not having Tamin out there quite as much in the first half impacted where the game was at. But man, in that second half, the plays he made, the shots he made, it was amazing ‚Äî especially when you have to bounce back when your normal routine and rhythm of a game is disrupted because of the fouls.‚Äù

After the Cyclones shot 27.8% from the field (10 of 36) in the first half, they were at 57.1% (16 of 28) after halftime.

On the defensive side, they held Baylor to 18.8% (6 of 32) before halftime and 30.6% (19 of 62) overall.

‚ÄúIowa State is a really good team. If you ask me, right now, today, them and Michigan are the two best in college basketball,‚Äù Baylor coach Scott Drew said. ‚ÄúThey‚Äôre not going to beat themselves. They know exactly where they‚Äôre going to be, how they‚Äôre going to do things. T.J. has done a great job with them.‚Äù

Get poll alerts and updates on the AP Top 25 throughout the season. AP college basketball: https://apnews.com/hub/ap-top-25-college-basketball-poll and https://apnews.com/hub/college-basketball

title: Utah Mammoth to host 2027 NHL Winter Classic vs. Colorado Avalanche in franchise's third season
description: The game will be played at University of Utah's Rice-Eccles Stadium in Salt Lake City.
fullText:
The Wasatch Mountain Range of the Greater Rockies will serve as the backdrop for the 2027 NHL Winter Classic. University of Utah's Rice-Eccles Stadium will be the site of the league's signature regular-season event, which the Utah Mammoth will host in the franchise's third season.

The Mammoth will welcome the Colorado Avalanche in a college football venue that seats approximately 51,400 on a fall Saturday in Salt Lake City.

The date of the game has yet to be finalized, but NHL commissioner Gary Bettman and Mammoth owners Ryan and Ashley Smith revealed the matchup Wednesday, along with Mammoth center Logan Cooley.

Logan Cooley on getting to play in the 2027 Winter Classic at Rice-Eccles Stadium: pic.twitter.com/SduTSBg5ah

‚Äî Jenna Fink (@jennamfink) January 7, 2026

The Mammoth, who formed after the Arizona Coyotes were dissolved in April 2024, are currently in their second season.

After an 8-2 start to the season, they're now 20-20-3 and in fourth place of the Central Division with 43 points.

This season, the Mammoth still have one more head-to-head meeting versus the Avalanche, who are the division leaders with a 31-4-7 record. Colorado is also atop the Western Conference at the moment with 69 points.

The Mammoth and Avalanche have met six times over the past two seasons, with Colorado holding a five-point advantage over Utah in the series. Their lone remaining matchup during the 2025-26 season is on Feb. 25 in Utah.

Next season's Winter Classic will mark the Avalanche's fourth appearance in an outdoor game. Utah, on the other hand, will soon become the 32nd NHL franchise to play in an outdoor game.

The Classic started as an annual tradition on Jan. 1, 2008. At the time, the Buffalo Sabres played the Pittsburgh Penguins at what was then known as Ralph Wilson Stadium in Orchard Park, New York, home of the NFL's Buffalo Bills.

This year's Winter Classic was held Jan. 2 at the Miami Marlins' loanDepot Park. The New York Rangers defeated the two-time defending Stanley Cup champion Florida Panthers 5-1.

It was the fifth straight Classic at a baseball stadium.

That streak will end next season in Salt Lake City, where the University of Utah's campus will take center stage, as Rice-Eccles becomes the fourth college football stadium to host the event.

Notably, Rice-Eccles also put on the Opening and Closing Ceremonies of the 2002 Winter Olympics. It's scheduled to fulfill the same role when the Games return to Utah in 2034.

title: I‚Äôm a brain scientist. These are five signs of cognitive decline ‚Äì and how to delay it
description: Ben Parris is a professor of cognition and cognitive neuroscience in Bournemouth University‚Äôs School of Psychology. He is also co-founder of the university‚Äôs Interdisciplinary Neuroscience Research Centre
fullText:
Ben Parris is a professor of cognition and cognitive neuroscience in Bournemouth University‚Äôs School of Psychology. He is also co-founder of the university‚Äôs Interdisciplinary Neuroscience Research Centre

A decline in your cognitive health is something that can creep up on you. It‚Äôs not like a bad back or dodgy knee, which will give you plenty of gyp as soon as there is a problem. You may suddenly find that you‚Äôre not quite as mentally sharp as you once were.

You may notice that it becomes harder to hold conversations, remember phone numbers and do everyday tasks such as go to the shops. That‚Äôs a result of your frontal lobe beginning to waste away, which happens to all of us as we age, though at different rates.

This part of the brain is located just behind our forehead and is home to our executive functions ‚Äì our ability to plan, organise, focus and generally interact with the world around us. It‚Äôs different from dementia, though that disease speeds up the process.

While the frontal lobe does eventually deteriorate, as a professor and researcher who studies cognitive decline, I have seen it remain in good nick in people in their 60s and beyond.

The key to keeping your mental abilities sharp as you age starts with noticing when the frontal lobe is shrinking. If you‚Äôre aware, there are things you can do to slow it down. So here are the signs it‚Äôs happening to you, and what you can do about it. I‚Äôve also compiled a series of tests so that you can test how well your brain is ageing, which you can access below.

One of the first signs of a decline in your cognitive health can be struggling to switch between tasks, such as cooking a meal while also holding a conversation with someone.

You might notice that you struggle to respond to someone‚Äôs comment, as you‚Äôre still thinking about what to do next in your recipe.

There is a loosening of the sharpness that was once there. The tasks bleed together, you‚Äôre not able to focus and it takes you a bit of time to adjust.

This signals a problem with your cognitive flexibility, which is the ability to switch between different tasks and remain focused. This represents one of the more difficult tasks that we engage in on a daily basis, so it can be the first ability that you notice is deteriorating.

In extreme cases, people can be stirring a pot and as they turn around to talk to someone, they are still doing the action of stirring but without the spoon in their hand.

We can all jumble up words at times, especially if we‚Äôre tired or distracted. However, if you catch yourself regularly skipping over words, it could be a sign of cognitive decline.

For example, instead of saying ‚ÄúI‚Äôm just going to pop to the shops‚Äù, you might come out with ‚ÄúI‚Äôm just shops‚Äù.

It can be a sign that there is a problem with your response inhibition, which is a cognitive function located in your frontal lobe. It is a skill we need for focus and to block out irrelevant information.

When you skip words like this, it means that your brain failed to inhibit (or block out) the last word in the sentence until it was time to say it. It‚Äôs a form of language breakdown that can be an early sign of dementia.

Regularly mixing up related words is another sign that your cognition isn‚Äôt in peak condition.

For example, if you want to say the word ‚Äúfork‚Äù, it should be at the forefront of your mind but, when there is a problem with response inhibition, related words such as ‚Äúspoon‚Äù and ‚Äúknife‚Äù can also float to the surface.

If this part of our cognitive function continues to deteriorate, you may say words that become increasingly distant from the word you meant to say, for example ‚Äúplate‚Äù or even ‚Äútrain‚Äù instead of ‚Äúfork‚Äù. This is a sign that there is misfiring going on in the brain.

The frequency with which this occurs and the distance from the word you intended to say can be used to determine the severity of cognitive decline.

If you realise that you need to nip to the shop for some milk, your brain quickly comes up with a plan. Where is the nearest shop? How will you get there? Do you have a way of paying?

With good cognitive health, this requires little effort and you may not give these questions a second thought. However, if one of these components goes wrong ‚Äì for example, you forget a means of payment ‚Äì it signals a failure in working memory, which is our ability to maintain and manipulate information.

As you were leaving the house, you failed to maintain one of the key components of the task. Such mental slips become more common as we age and our frontal lobes atrophy.

If this happens occasionally and is not increasing in frequency, it‚Äôs nothing to worry about. I have been known to drive to the supermarket and walk home, forgetting that I‚Äôve left the car as I‚Äôve been busy thinking about other things.

However, if it happens more and more often, you might want to consider seeing your GP. It could be an early sign of dementia.

Forgetting what you need from the shop, and struggling to find the items you want to buy, are signs of cognitive decline.

You rely on your short-term memory to remember what you need from the shop and your spatial memory (the ability to understand where you are in relation to your surroundings) to be able to find the products you need.

If this part of your cognitive health is deteriorating, you may find yourself walking up and down the same aisles many times, as you‚Äôve forgotten which you‚Äôve already been down.

One famous study took patients to a shopping centre and gave them a list of items to buy, such as milk and a newspaper. Those suffering from cognitive decline walked up and down multiple times, getting the items in an illogical way, following an incoherent path.

If you are experiencing any of these symptoms and it is significantly affecting your ability to continue with life as normal, or you have noticed that they are getting worse, I would recommend going to your GP.

It‚Äôs also worth booking an appointment with your doctor if a loved one is concerned about your cognitive health, even if you are not, as you could be experiencing anosognosia, which is a lack of awareness of your own cognitive decline. This is a common problem.

While these symptoms could be a sign of cognitive decline or dementia, they could also be caused by a stroke or tumour. The earlier you see your GP, the easier it is to treat.

If concerned, your doctor should refer you to the neuropsychology clinic at your local hospital. There, you will probably complete a series of memory tests, such as the ‚ÄúStroop task‚Äù and the Corsi block-tapping test, and have an MRI to look for shrinkage in the frontal lobe, which would indicate dementia, or lesions, which may be evidence of a stroke.

There are no hidden secrets in terms of maintaining cognitive health. As far as we‚Äôre aware, it‚Äôs the same recommendations as for maintaining bodily health.

Diet and exercise are the two most important pillars to focus on for your brain.

Following a healthy diet ‚Äì which includes plenty of green leafy vegetables, fish, nuts and berries ‚Äì has been shown to slow cognitive decline, which is thought to be because these foods contain nutrients such as folate and omega-3 fatty acids.

Weight-training twice a week has been linked to less brain shrinkage and better performance on memory tests, while cardio improves blood flow, including to the brain, promoting the development of new brain cells and protecting the organ against inflammation.

I always recommend cutting back on alcohol ‚Äì and only drink a few times a year myself ‚Äì as research has shown that it causes shrinkage in parts of the brain important for memory, and poorer performance on cognitive tests. I‚Äôd also recommend quitting drinking alcohol alone, as the only benefits thought to come from drinking is if it gets you out socialising.

It‚Äôs possible that the deterioration of our frontal lobe happens, or is sped up, due to a lack of use, and challenging your brain has been linked with delaying cognitive decline. This could mean learning a new instrument or language, reading difficult books, doing calculations in your head instead of on your phone calculator, completing puzzles, and even watching quiz shows. They can all play a role in keeping your brain younger.

Spending time in nature has been linked to better working memory, while holding conversations, and socialising has been shown to keep our cognitive health better for longer. Whether it‚Äôs having a conversation or making plans to meet loved ones, you‚Äôre working those cognitive muscles.

title: SCOTUS Justice‚Äôs Blistering Dissent Vindicated by Bombshell Study
description: A new study has bolstered a scathing dissent from liberal Supreme Court Justice Ketanji Brown Jackson that warned the court appeared to favor the rich. The study, published Monday by the National Bureau of Economic Research, investigated whether the Supreme Court has contributed to rising income inequality by ruling in favor of policies that favor wealthy parties. Its authors‚Äîtwo academics from Columbia University in New York and one from Yale University‚Äîfound that in cases pitting the rich agai
fullText:
A new study has bolstered a scathing dissent from liberal Supreme Court Justice Ketanji Brown Jackson that warned the court appeared to favor the rich.

The study, published Monday by the National Bureau of Economic Research, investigated whether the Supreme Court has contributed to rising income inequality by ruling in favor of policies that favor wealthy parties.

Its authors‚Äîtwo academics from Columbia University in New York and one from Yale University‚Äîfound that in cases pitting the rich against the poor, Republican appointees were far more likely than their Democratic colleagues to side with the wealthier party.

Back in 1953, Democratic and Republican appointees were statistically indistinguishable on the issue, with justices appointed by members of both parties favoring the rich in 45 percent of cases on average.

The average Democratic justice cast a ‚Äúpro-rich‚Äù vote‚Äîwhich was defined as a vote that would directly shift resources to the party that was more likely to be wealthy, including votes that supported businesses over consumers or workers‚Äîjust 35 percent of the time.

‚ÄúThe results reveal a steady increase in polarization, mostly due to Republican appointees whose decisions rise from about 50 percent pro-rich share to a 70 percent pro-rich share over the course of 70 years,‚Äù the study‚Äôs authors, Andrea Prat, a Columbia economics professor, Jacob Spitz, a Columbia PhD student, Fiona Scott Morton, a Yale economics professor, and wrote.

The findings also supported a June dissent authored by Brown Jackson, according to The New York Times.

The justices held 7-2 that oil and gas companies had legal standing to challenge California‚Äôs environmental regulations requiring automakers to produce more electric vehicles and fewer gasoline-powered ones.

‚ÄúThis case gives fodder to the unfortunate perception that moneyed interests enjoy an easier road to relief in this Court than ordinary citizens,‚Äù Brown Jackson wrote. ‚ÄúI worry that the fuel industry‚Äôs gain comes at a reputational cost for this Court, which is already viewed by many as being overly sympathetic to corporate interests.‚Äù

That perception could be contributing to an overall drop in public confidence in the court, according to the Times. The Daily Beast has reached out to the Supreme Court for comment.

The court‚Äôs favorability rating has plunged by 22 points over the past five years, from 70 percent in 2020 to a near-record low 48 percent late last year, the Pew Research Center reported in September.

And although a vast majority of Americans, or 86 percent, think the justices should be non-partisan, 56 percent said the justices were doing only a fair or poor job of keeping their political views out of their legal decision-making.

title: Cougars control the paint, take down Briar Cliff
description: SIOUX FALLS, S.D. (USF) ‚Äî The University of Sioux Falls men‚Äôs basketball team kept their momentum rolling on Monday afternoon, grinding out an 81‚Äì75 victory over Briar Cliff inside the Stewart Center. The win pushed the Cougars‚Äô winning streak to four games in a physical, paint-dominated battle that required clutch execution and second-half composure to put [‚Ä¶]
fullText:
SIOUX FALLS, S.D. (USF) ‚Äî¬†The University of Sioux Falls men‚Äôs basketball team kept their momentum rolling on Monday afternoon, grinding out an 81‚Äì75 victory over Briar Cliff inside the Stewart Center. The win pushed the Cougars‚Äô winning streak to four games in a physical, paint-dominated battle that required clutch execution and second-half composure to put away a scrappy Charger squad.

This was a blue-collar victory through and through. Both teams traded blows in a back-and-forth contest that stayed tight for the better part of 40 minutes. Sioux Falls shot an efficient 50 percent from the field (32-of-64), methodically attacking the rim and imposing their will in the paint while Briar Cliff refused to go away quietly.

Four Cougars reached double figures, led by¬†Brogan Madson‚Äôs¬†team-high 21 points, as USF found ways to score even when the perimeter game went cold. The difference came after halftime, where Sioux Falls outscored the Chargers 43‚Äì37 behind relentless interior scoring and timely free-throw shooting that ultimately sealed the deal.

Taylen Ashley¬†and Madson combined for 21 second-half points, while¬†Brandon Hrncir¬†delivered a perfect shooting performance after the break. When the dust settled, it was the Cougars‚Äô dominance on the glass and their poise in crunch time that made the difference in the six-point win.

Briar Cliff came out sharp, connecting on 15-of-31 from the floor while Sioux Falls answered with a 15-of-33 effort. Neither team found a rhythm from deep‚ÄîUSF managed just 2-of-10 from three while the Chargers hit 4-of-13. The Cougars established their identity early, however, bullying Briar Cliff inside for a 24‚Äì16 paint advantage.

The first 20 minutes featured five lead changes and four ties as neither squad could create separation. Ball security was excellent on both sides with just two turnovers apiece, and the rebounding battle stayed competitive with USF holding a narrow 20‚Äì17 edge. The teams headed to the locker room deadlocked after a tightly contested opening half.

Sioux Falls took control after intermission, outscoring Briar Cliff 43‚Äì37 to close out the victory. The paint remained the Cougars‚Äô domain, where they pounded out a 28‚Äì16 scoring advantage in the half. Ashley sparked the offense with 11 second-half points while Madson added 10 more, consistently attacking a tiring Charger defense.

Hrncir was surgical in the second half‚Äîa flawless 4-for-4 from the field for nine points while pulling down five rebounds. The Cougars crashed the offensive glass for seven second-half boards, creating extra possessions at critical moments. When the game was on the line, Madson calmly sank all of his free throws to ice the win.

‚ÄúIt was good to keep our winning streak going. We didn‚Äôt play our best basketball, but give Briar Cliff a lot of credit for that. We found a way, and now we need to get back to practice and get ready for road games at Duluth and Bemidji.‚Äù
‚Äî Head Coach¬†Chris Johnson

Brogan Madson¬†‚Äì 21 points (8-of-14 FG), 3 assists

Taylen Ashley¬†‚Äì 19 points, 4 rebounds

Brandon Hrncir¬†‚Äì 19 points (8-of-11 FG), 9 rebounds, 3 assists

Kyle Ingwerson¬†‚Äì 10 points, 7 rebounds

Paint:¬†Sioux Falls owned a 52‚Äì32 advantage in points in the paint.

Rebounding:¬†The Cougars outrebounded Briar Cliff 42‚Äì28, including 10 offensive rebounds.

Shooting:¬†USF finished at 50.0 percent from the field while holding Briar Cliff to fewer second-half opportunities inside.

Balance:¬†Four Cougars scored in double figures, providing consistent offense throughout the lineup.

Free Throws:¬†Sioux Falls went 12-of-17 at the line, converting key attempts late.

The Cougars hit the road next weekend, traveling to face¬†Minnesota Duluth on January 9¬†and¬†Bemidji State on January 10.

title: Read the memo AT&T sent staff about moving its global HQ to the Dallas suburbs
description: AT&T said a new corporate campus in Plano, Texas, would consolidate three existing locations in the Dallas area, including a downtown skyscraper.
fullText:
AT&T is ditching downtown Dallas for the suburbs.

The telecom giant said Monday it plans to move its global headquarters to a newly constructed corporate campus in Plano, Texas, starting in 2028.

The new global headquarters would consolidate three existing locations in the Dallas area, including the downtown skyscraper that has been AT&T's home since 2008.

A spokesperson told Business Insider that the new facilities will be designed for "collaboration, innovation, and engagement," and that the company still believes the Dallas-Fort Worth metro area is¬†a good location¬†for business.

Like many companies that have instituted full-time return-to-office policies, AT&T has experienced shortages of workspace and parking. AT&T said it has been developing the plan for the new headquarters for the past year.

Several north Dallas suburbs are among the fastest-growing cities and towns in the US, and AT&T's spokesperson said the new campus will be closer to where many employees live.

In a memo to employees, which Business Insider obtained, CEO John Stankey acknowledged feedback about expectations for "well-maintained and functional workspaces" that were raised in an engagement survey last year.

"This is an investment intended to put the employee experience at the center of our workspace," Stankey said.

title: Greece cuts student population at universities by half after long study breaks are abolished
description: More than 300,000 inactive university students have been removed from the rolls in Greece, cutting the country‚Äôs official student population by nearly half, authorities said Friday.  On Friday, the Education Ministry said that 308,605 students admitted to state-run universities‚Äô four-year degree programs before 2017 had been removed from the records.  ‚ÄúStudent status is not valid for life in any modern European university," Education Minister Sofia Zacharaki said.
fullText:
ATHENS, Greece (AP) ‚Äî More than 300,000 inactive university students have been removed from the rolls in Greece, cutting the country‚Äôs official student population by nearly half, authorities said Friday.

The move marks the end of a decadeslong practice ‚Äî formally abolished in recent legislation ‚Äî that allowed extended enrollment to facilitate lifelong learning and lengthy breaks for work.

On Friday, the Education Ministry said that 308,605 students admitted to state-run universities‚Äô four-year degree programs before 2017 had been removed from the records.

‚ÄúStudent status is not valid for life in any modern European university," Education Minister Sofia Zacharaki said. "We want degrees with value, which reflect effort, skills and passion.‚Äù

Ministry officials said that about 35,000 people successfully applied for reenrollment in 2025.

Opponents of the conservative government's reform, mostly from the academic community, argue the second-chance program failed to address the scale of disruption caused by Greece‚Äôs severe financial crisis in the previous decade.

The country's active student population stands at just over 350,000, studying at 25 public higher education institutions, according to 2024 data from the Hellenic Authority for Higher Education.

Undergraduate degree programs at state universities are normally funded by the government. Until recently, only public universities offering state-recognized degrees have operated in Greece. But recognized private universities are gradually being introduced.

Education Ministry officials said that dormant students ‚Äî those who had interrupted their studies ‚Äî didn't impose any direct financial burden on universities, but created administrative difficulties.

‚ÄúWith updated student lists, universities gain the ability to plan more precisely,‚Äù Deputy Education Minister Nikos Papaioannou said.

‚ÄúThat is a prerequisite for improving academic quality, daily operations and the criteria used to evaluate Greek universities in international rankings.‚Äù

title: What's inside Mexico's Popocat√©petl? Scientists obtain first 3D images of the whole volcano
description: POPOCAT√âPETL VOLCANO, Mexico (AP) ‚Äî In the predawn darkness, a team of scientists climbs the slope of Mexico's Popocat√©petl volcano, one of the world‚Äôs most active and whose eruption could affect millions of people.  For five years, the group from Mexico‚Äôs National Autonomous University has climbed the volcano with kilos of equipment, risked data loss due to bad weather or a volcanic explosion and used artificial intelligence to analyze the seismic data.  Now, the team has created the first three-dimensional image of the whole 17,883-foot (5,452-meter) volcano‚Äôs interior, which tells them where the magma accumulates and will help them better understand its activity, and, eventually, help authorities better react to eruptions.
fullText:
POPOCAT√âPETL VOLCANO, Mexico (AP) ‚Äî In the predawn darkness, a team of scientists climbs the slope of Mexico's Popocat√©petl volcano, one of the world‚Äôs most active and whose eruption could affect millions of people. Its mission: figure out what is happening under the crater.

For five years, the group from Mexico‚Äôs National Autonomous University has climbed the volcano with kilos of equipment, risked data loss due to bad weather or a volcanic explosion and used artificial intelligence to analyze the seismic data. Now, the team has created the first three-dimensional image of the whole 17,883-foot (5,452-meter) volcano‚Äôs interior, which tells them where the magma accumulates and will help them better understand its activity, and, eventually, help authorities better react to eruptions.

Marco Cal√≤, professor in the UNAM's Geophysics Institute‚Äôs vulcanology department and the project leader, invited The Associated Press to accompany the team on its most recent expedition, the last before its research on the volcano will be published.

Inside an active volcano, everything is moving: the rocks, magma, gas and aquifers. It all generates seismic signals.

Most of the world‚Äôs volcanoes that pose a risk to humans already have detailed maps of their interiors, but not Popocat√©petl, despite the fact that some 25 million people live within a 62-mile (100 kilometers) radius and houses, schools, hospitals and five airports could be affected by an eruption.

Other scientists took some early images 15 years ago, but they showed contradictory results and did not have sufficient resolution to see ‚Äúhow the volcanic edifice was being built,‚Äù and above all, where the magma gathered, Cal√≤ said.

His team increased the number of seismographs from the 12 provided by Mexico‚Äôs National Disaster Prevention Center to 22 to cover the entire perimeter of the volcano. Even though just three can alert to an emergency, many more are needed to understand what is behind those emergencies.

The devices measure vibrations in the ground 100 times per second and generate data that Karina Bernal, 33, a doctoral student and researcher on the project, processed by using artificial intelligence to adapt algorithms developed for other volcanoes.

‚ÄúI taught the machine about the different types of tremors there are in El Popo‚Äù and with that they were able to catalog the different kinds of seismic signals, she said.

Little by little the scientists began to infer what kinds of material were where, in what state, at what temperature and at what depth. Later they were able to map it.

The result is far more complex than the drawings of volcanoes most saw in school, with a main vent connecting a chamber of magma with the surface.

This first three-dimensional cross-sectional image goes 11 miles (18 kilometers) below the crater and shows what appear to be various pools of magma at different depths, with rock or other material between them and more numerous toward the southeast of the crater.

Popocat√©petl emerged in the crater of other volcanoes in its current form more than 20,000 years ago and has been active since 1994, spewing plumes of smoke, gas and ash more or less daily. The activity periodically forms a dome over the main vent, which eventually collapses, causing an eruption. The last was in 2023.

Cal√≤, a 46-year-old Sicilian, speaks passionately about El Popo, as Mexicans call the volcano, rattling off trivia.

He explains that its height can change because of eruptions and recounts how Popocat√©petl, in the first century, had its own ‚Äúlittle Pompeii‚Äù when a village on its flanks, Tetimpa, was buried in ash. In the early 20th century, it was human actions ‚Äî using dynamite to extract sulfur from the crater ‚Äî that provoked an eruption. And even though El Popo emanates more greenhouse gases than almost any other volcano, its emissions are still a small fraction of what humans generate in nearby Mexico City.

For years Cal√≤ studied volcanic activity from his computer, but trying to ‚Äúunderstand how something works without touching it‚Äù spurred a feeling of disappointment, he said.

That changed with Popocat√©petl, a volcano he describes as ‚Äúmajestic.‚Äù

After hours of walking up the volcano‚Äôs flank, Cal√≤‚Äôs team sets up camp in a pine grove at about 12,500 feet of elevation, an apparent safe spot from pyroclastic explosions, since the trees have managed to grow to significant height.

A short distance higher on the mountain, the trees and scrub give way to ash and sediment.

They must cross a lahar, a mixture of rock and ash that during the rainy season becomes a dangerous mudflow carrying away everything in its path. Now, the dry clearing provides a spectacular view: to the east the Pico de Orizaba ‚Äî Mexico‚Äôs tallest volcano and mountain and the dormant volcano La Malinche; to the north, Iztacc√≠huatl, an inactive volcanic peak known as ‚Äúthe sleeping woman.‚Äù

Popocat√©petl‚Äôs sounds seem to multiply at night with the echoes. An explosion like a rocket might sound like it‚Äôs coming from one direction, but a puff of smoke from the crater belies the real source.

Karina Rodr√≠guez, a 26-year-old master‚Äôs student on the team, said you can also hear small tremors in the earth or even ash falling like rain when the volcano is more active. On dark nights, the rim of the crater glows orange.

Having direct knowledge of the volcano provides a much more objective sense of the limits of their analysis, Cal√≤ said.

‚ÄúWe have a natural laboratory here,‚Äù he said. It‚Äôs ‚Äúvery important to be able to understand and give residents detailed, trustworthy information about what is happening inside the volcano.‚Äù

At 13,780 feet (4,200 meters), their backpacks full of computers, equipment to analyze gases, batteries and water begin to weigh more and their pace slows.

Ash, dark and warm, dominates the landscape here.

At a seismographic station, the team digs up the equipment and celebrates that it‚Äôs still working. They download its data and rebury it.

A ‚Äúvolcanic bomb,‚Äù a rock a yard and a half in diameter and weighing tons, marks the way and gives an idea of what the start of an eruption can mean. That is why the top area of the volcano is restricted, though not everyone pays heed. In 2022, a person died after being hit by a rock about 300 yards (meters) from the crater.

A bottle of tequila near a rocky hollow, known as El Popo‚Äôs belly button, hints at some of the traditions surrounding the volcano, including an annual pilgrimage to what some consider a point of connection to the underworld.

Digging up one of the last seismic stations, Cal√≤‚Äôs face falls. The last registered data are from months earlier. The battery died. Sometimes rats chew the machines‚Äô wires or an explosion causes more serious damage.

The project has yielded some certainties and if repeated will allow the analysis of changes that eventually will help authorities make better decisions when eruptions occur.

But Cal√≤ says that, as always happens with science, it has also generated new questions that they will have to try to address, like why the tremors are more frequent on the southeast side ‚Äî where there is more accumulated magma ‚Äî and what implications that could have.

This was the last expedition before their years of work to map the volcano‚Äôs interior is published. Watching the volcano‚Äôs interior move in 3D on a computer screen makes all of the effort worthwhile.

‚ÄúIt‚Äôs what drives you to start another project and keep climbing,‚Äù Rodr√≠guez, the master's student, said.

title: Protesting students in Serbia urge support for early election they hope will oust Vucic
description: Serbia's protesting university students on Sunday collected signatures throughout the country for their request for an early parliamentary election that they hope would oust the autocratic government of President Aleksandar Vucic from office.  Braving freezing weather, the students set up nearly 500 stands in dozens of cities, towns and villages in the Balkan country for residents to sign the election demand, which isn't a formal petition.  Students have said that Sunday‚Äôs action was meant to put further pressure on Vucic and as a test of support.
fullText:
BELGRADE, Serbia (AP) ‚Äî Serbia's protesting university students on Sunday collected signatures throughout the country for their request for an early parliamentary election that they hope would oust the autocratic government of President Aleksandar Vucic from office.

Braving freezing weather, the students set up nearly 500 stands in dozens of cities, towns and villages in the Balkan country for residents to sign the election demand, which isn't a formal petition. Students have said that Sunday‚Äôs action was meant to put further pressure on Vucic and as a test of support.

Young protesters have been at the forefront of a nationwide movement against Vucic's populist rule in Serbia. More than a year of street protests first started in November 2024 after a train station disaster that killed 16 people.

The concrete canopy collapse in the northern city of Novi Sad was widely blamed on alleged rampant corruption and disregard of construction and safety rules during renovation work at the station. No one has been held responsible for the tragedy.

Vucic has refused to schedule an immediate early vote, but has suggested that it could be held sometime next year. Both parliamentary and presidential elections are otherwise due in 2027.

‚ÄúWe have stands that serve to connect with the citizens," said Igor Dojnov, a student manning one of the points in central Belgrade.

Youth-led protests during the past year have shaken Vucic more than ever during his 13-year-long tenure. Serbia's populist prime minister resigned in January, and Vucic later launched a crackdown on protesters that also drew international criticism.

While street protests have subsided, discontent with Vucic's government is believed to be widespread.

Milca Cankovic Kadijevic, a resident of Belgrade, said that she supported the students, because ‚ÄúI have a desire to live decently ‚Äî me, my children and my grandchildren."

Vucic has formally promised to take Serbia into the European Union, but he has maintained close links with Russia and China, while facing accusations of clamping down on democratic freedoms and allowing corruption and organized crime to flourish.

He has denied this, and accused the protesters of attempting to orchestrate a ‚Äúcolor revolution‚Äù under unspecified orders from the West. The term ‚Äúcolor revolution‚Äù has been used to describe a series of mass protests at the beginning of the 21st century that sometimes led to the toppling of governments in the former Soviet Union states, the former Yugoslavia, the Middle East and Asia.

title: World's smallest autonomous robots could one day save your life
description: Scientists from the University of Pennsylvania (Penn) and the University of Michigan have created the world's smallest autonomous and programmable robots. Each measuring about 200 micrometers wide ‚Äì roughly twice the width of a human hair ‚Äì these machines can perceive their surroundings, "think,"‚Ä¶
fullText:
Scientists from the University of Pennsylvania (Penn) and the University of Michigan have created the world's smallest autonomous and programmable robots. Each measuring about 200 micrometers wide ‚Äì roughly twice the width of a human hair ‚Äì these machines can perceive their surroundings, "think," and act independently without external instructions. According to their developers, such technology could one day monitor the health of individual cells in our bodies or deliver medication to specific locations to treat diseases.

The researchers' major breakthrough was enabling a robot just one-fifth of a millimeter long to move autonomously without external assistance, a challenge scientists have been trying to solve for decades. Physical forces such as drag and viscosity have a much stronger effect on objects at the microscopic scale, making movement through a liquid comparable to swimming through tar at the human scale.

To overcome this challenge, the Penn team designed a new propulsion system. The microrobots are powered by LED light and operate in a hydrogen peroxide solution, which provides the fuel for their movement. The robot generates an electric field that propels the ions in the surrounding solution, which in turn drag water molecules along. The microrobots can adjust this electric field to move in complex patterns and even travel in coordinated groups at speeds of up to one body length per second.

The world's smallest autonomous robot requires the world's smallest computer. That title belongs to a computer developed by David Blaauw's team at Michigan. The researchers adapted their microcomputer to Penn's propulsion system and built a complete computer with a processor, memory, and sensors on a chip less than a millimeter across.

The robot receives light through microscopic solar panels that generate only 75 nanowatts of power ‚Äì over 100,000 times less than a smartwatch, according to Blaauw. His team had to make the microcomputer circuits operate at extremely low voltages, reducing power consumption by more than a factor of 1,000.

Perhaps the most striking feature is the overall system cost. Although each robot costs about one cent to produce at scale, one might assume that the equipment needed to program and control them would be prohibitively expensive. That is not the case.

"It‚Äôs about $100," Marc Miskin, a professor at Penn Engineering and lead author of the study, told me by email. The team has already built a low-cost version of their setup using standard LED diodes, a Raspberry Pi microcomputer, and an imaging system consisting of a smartphone camera fitted with a macro lens. "This system actually performs about as well as our fancy $100k microscope. Because the robot is doing all the hard work, it doesn't need you to tell it what to do," Miskin explained.

The microrobots feature electronic sensors capable of detecting temperature with a precision of one-third of a degree Celsius, allowing them to monitor the health of individual cells. However, several obstacles remain before this technology can be applied to human health.

Just like the cells in our bodies, which require a constant energy supply to survive, the microrobots cannot function without continuous light. "If you turn off the light, the robot turns off and the memory gets cleared," Miskin said. "Turn the light back on, and it will reboot, but won't remember what you programmed it to do. This is a common feature of sub-mm systems, because the total energy you can store (e.g. a battery) scales with its volume, it's extremely hard to store any useful amount in a small space."

But there‚Äôs another challenge, in their current version, the robots operate in a 5-millimolar hydrogen peroxide solution, which is toxic to living cells. This makes them unsuitable for medical applications in their present form. The researchers acknowledge this limitation, but it is not insurmountable. Because the robot is electronically integrated, actuators can be swapped freely, you only need to match the operating voltage and required current. "We're actively working on building the corresponding robots, integrating these bio-compatible actuators with circuits, and you'll hopefully see some of these soon," Miskin explained.

Miskin is even more excited about something else: using these robots to assemble microscale components. "Almost everything we build at the microscale these days is made all at once, monolithically," he said. "For example, when we build circuits, we make them out of these complex patterns on big wafers. If you want to change one part of that circuit, you have to rebuild the whole thing."

The researchers argue this could lower costs, speed up design iterations, and even simplify intellectual property. "The microscale is an amazing place," Miskin noted. "Having little agents that humans can program and control could open up all kinds of remarkable doors. I'm cautiously optimistic the best applications have yet to be imagined."

title: Aloha Stadium demolition signals long-awaited progress on new venue
description: The demolition of Hawai‚Äôi‚Äôs Aloha Stadium is finally underway after several delays.Once home to the NFL Pro Bowl, college football‚Äôs Hawai ªi Bowl and University of Hawai ªi football, Aloha Stadium is transitioning into a new scaled-down stadium with an accompanying entertainment district. As part of the New Aloha Stadium Entertainment District (NASED) project, the new stadium is set for a projected grand opening in March 2029, and is expected to have a seating capacity of 22,500, less than half o
fullText:
The demolition of Hawai‚Äôi‚Äôs Aloha Stadium is finally underway after several delays.

Once home to the NFL Pro Bowl, college football‚Äôs Hawai ªi Bowl and University of Hawai ªi football, Aloha Stadium is transitioning into a new scaled-down stadium with an accompanying entertainment district.

As part of the New Aloha Stadium Entertainment District (NASED) project, the new stadium is set for a projected grand opening in March 2029, and is expected to have a seating capacity of 22,500, less than half of the previous 50,000 seats it held.

‚ÄúThe demolition/dismantling of Aloha Stadium has begun,‚Äù Aloha Stadium Authority chairman Eric Fujimoto said at the NASED monthly meeting on Dec. 18. The removal of furnishings and the subsequent dismantling of the facility are expected to take approximately 10 months.

The beginning of the demolition process marks a major milestone for a plan that has been repeatedly delayed. The reopening of the stadium was initially scheduled to be on time for the Rainbow Warriors‚Äô football season in 2028, but was pushed back to 2029 in August of this year.

Before its final closing after years of maintenance issues, Aloha Stadium was an innovative steel-constructed venue with movable seating sections for different sports and events.

However, the stadium, also known as the Metal Mecca, met its downfall because of that very design structure.

The steel structure was not a good match for Hawai‚Äôi‚Äôs humid climate, which led to severe, damaging rust that required frequent repairs.

During the COVID-19 pandemic in 2020, the stadium with a costly history was put to rest.

With the demolition now in full swing, attention turns to the broader vision of the NASED project. The construction of the new, smaller stadium and the surrounding entertainment district is expected to cost the state $350 million.

The new Aloha Stadium‚Äôs entertainment district is expected to include 4,000 to 4,500 housing units, multiple hotels, retail and dining spaces and cultural attractions. Residential construction is projected to take place shortly after the opening of the newly renovated Aloha Stadium, as early as 2029 or 2030.

Diego Rivera - The Sporting Tribune

The University of Hawai'i Rainbow Warriors celebrate linebacker Jalen Smith's (3) fumble recovery during an NCAA football game against the Utah State Aggies, Saturday, October 11, 2025.

After playing its home games at the Clarence T.C. Ching Athletics Complex since the closing of Aloha Stadium, University of Hawai‚Äôi football is set to move back into the new facility in 2029 under a license agreement negotiated with Hawai‚Äôi Athletics Director Matt Elliott.

‚ÄúWhile there is still much work ahead, the progress being made gives all of us reason to be optimistic,‚Äù Elliott said in a September press release. ‚ÄúWe are excited to see momentum building and remain committed to doing our part to bring this long-awaited vision to life.‚Äù

As demolition progresses and construction plans take shape, the NASED project ushers in a new era for Hawai‚Äôi sports.

title: LaBrae basketball standout commits to the next level

fullText:
LEAVITTSBURGH, Ohio (WKBN) ‚Äì LaBrae boys basketball star Austin Rowe has committed to continue his academic and athletic careers at Mount Vernon Nazarene University.

The senior announced his commitment on social media this week.

Rowe averaged 17.6 points as a junior for the Vikings. He also will have 12 varsity letters by the end of his senior year.

title: The brothers from Dagestan shining in MMA and for Man Utd
description: The Ibragimov family moved from Dagestan to England with their sights on university - but they are excelling in sport instead.
fullText:
Ibragim Ibragimov cracks a smile as he reflects on how his family's life has changed since moving to England from Dagestan eight years ago.

"I love it here," the Professional Fighters League (PFL) star tells BBC Sport.

"My dad and I always say, 'this is the country I should have been born in'."

The 21-year-old left his home in the North Caucasus region in 2017 because his father believed a move more than 3,000 miles across Europe would offer better career opportunities for him and his siblings.

The plan was for Ibragim and his three brothers - Amir (17), Gazik (16), and Muhammad (15) - to finish school before enrolling in one of the country's universities.

But life looks slightly different for the Ibragimov family now.

Ibragim is a professional mixed martial arts fighter and is regarded as one of the top prospects in PFL, one of the leading MMA leagues.

His brothers have taken a different path in sport and have all been signed by Manchester United - with Amir pushing for a place in the first team.

"The main thing for us is to squeeze everything out of our sports," says Ibragim.

"I want them to play for all of the best teams in the world. Today it is Man Utd, tomorrow it could be a different team."

title: I left my university in Milan to study in a much smaller town. I loved the lower cost of living and slower pace.
description: I thought I would enjoy attending a private university in Milan. I quickly learned I had made the wrong choice.
fullText:
I crossed the street near where I was living in Milan on the verge of tears. I had had enough of feeling sad, lonely, and hopeless.

That surely wasn't how I expected to feel in my first year of university.

The previous spring, I had thought about which undergraduate degree I wanted to pursue for months, reading about courses, tuition, and life in a new place. Since I loved writing and dreamed of becoming a journalist, studying communication seemed like the best bet. I chose to pursue a degree at a private university in Milan because the classes seemed fascinating and useful, and the idea of living in Milan was thrilling.

Unfortunately, I soon realized I had made the wrong choice.

The majority of the courses I was taking were engaging, but we occasionally experienced last-minute schedule changes and disorganized lecturers, and that didn't sit right with me.

More importantly, I began to feel guilty about the expenses my parents were covering for me. They assured me they could afford it and that my education was worthwhile to them; nonetheless, the tuition and rent were expensive. And, if I wasn't loving it, should they be spending so much?

Living in Milan was way more exciting in my dreams than it was in reality. While this metropolis had a lot to offer, like cultural exhibitions, sports events, and a lively nightlife, it was also chaotic and hectic. I often felt agitated and restless.

In my first months there, my sleep was severely affected. It was extremely challenging to find accommodation near the university, and I ended up in a small apartment with a shared bedroom. I struggled to adapt to that living situation and to the noisy neighborhood we lived in.

The following summer, I applied to the University of Urbino. The living costs and slower rhythms of Urbino, a 15,000-inhabitant town located a short distance from where I grew up in San Marino, were way more appealing to me.

There, I could attend classes just three days a week, so finding an accommodation wasn't an urgent matter anymore. It was manageable to go back and forth by car from my family home in the first month.

After that period, I rented a single room with a stunning view, at a walkable distance from my lecture halls. The morning walk in Urbino's historical center to class became a pleasurable part of my day.

I felt relieved because the public university tuition and accommodation in Urbino were much cheaper than what I was paying in Milan. Given the flexibility of my new arrangement and the saved money, I signed up for a fitness course with training branches in Urbino and San Marino, as well as a mindfulness program in Rimini. I was brighter and more serene.

Unfortunately, this period in Urbino didn't last long, because COVID-19 hit and universities implemented online lessons, and I eventually ended up moving back home.

Looking back, those few months in Urbino were the best period of my early 20s, and I'm glad I was courageous enough to know that something wasn't right and that I could do something about it, and that's a lesson that still sticks with me today.
